heartland they're a Sunni regime he's
gone now where are the Sunnis left in
Iran it's an important question to see
but i think you know looking at that
Sunni narrative since 2003 goes a long
way in explaining all that's happened in
Iraq basically post-war post-invasion
there was Sunni resistance in the new
order which led to the insurgency there
was Sunni incorporation into the
political process and we saw that
manifested I think most clearly in the
elections March 7th these elections that
were seen by a month seen as a milestone
by many the question of what's next for
the Sunnis i think is very compelling
and i think we feel a lot of people feel
that we're at a crossroads at an
intersection on which way the Sunnis go
there's a sense among Sunni politicians
that if Sunnis don't reach some of their
ambitions some of their goals and these
current negotiations these deadlock
negotiations namely having their cannon
to become the Prime Minister we could go
back to more precarious unpredictable
time is there any chance that their
candidate yet allow me I'll be at
himself a secular Shia could win could
be appointed Prime Minister well there's
no question that Sunni politicians that
the Sunni leadership has invested their
hopes in a yacht allow as next prime
minister I think when you talk to
diplomats you talk to officials you talk
to politicians themselves the chances of
a yellowy becoming Prime Minister are
extremely remote perhaps impossible I
think there's a notion among the
leadership in the country the same
leadership that we've had since 2003
basically that a yet allowed becoming
Prime Minister would represent what they
call a Sunni restoration in other words
the Sunni community in Iraq a minority
will get to choose the person from the
most powerful post in the country the
prime ministership that position is seen
to be a she I position it's also seem to
be a position that the Shiite majority
will choose soon as you talk to say we
played the game according to the rules
you lay down we participated in election
our chosen coalition got the largest
number of seats and still the incumbents
are trying to marginalize us try to
squeeze us out and there is an
undercurrent of warning there but well
if we can't get it this way who knows
what the future will hold where do you
see things going from here it was a
great question i think what we're going
to see next if this does come to pass
we'll probably see in the most general
terms is a government lacking legitimacy
in the eyes of a large share of its
population does that mean war does that
mean instability does that mean some
kind of morphus unrest it's really
difficult to say at this point I think
we you can clearly acknowledged as the
Sunnis lost the insurgency in some ways
they lost the Civil War do they really
have the capacity or even the
willingness to resort back to arms to
create more unrest like we saw in
earlier years it's difficult to imagine
although of course not impossible but we
have to understand is that politics in
Iraq in 2010 are still motivated by fear
it's the fear among the Shia community
of a Sunni restoration in some respects
and I'm going to say this Shia community
in general the Shiite leadership and
especially the religious leadership
there's definitely a fear out of among
among Sunnis that they're going to be
permanently marginalized in this point
of a process that's going forward you
can understand where both are coming
from however remote those fears actually
might be
